awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Dense, Socially-Compliant, Autonomous Delivery Robot
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is to enable autonomous mobile robots (AMRs) to operate in densely crowded spaces in a safe and socially compliant/acceptable manner. A key potential outcome is the development of a collision avoidance method based on Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL).  This method would be capable of handling dense crowds and optimized to run on compact and power-efficient embedded processors. Such abilities would increase the commercial potential and adoption of learning-based navigation methods that have demonstrated excellent collision avoidance and noise handling capabilities. The technology may unlock commercial opportunities by deploying AMRs in the airport, retail, healthcare, and hospitality industries, where the environments are highly dense and dynamic. The airport industry may derive postive impacts from AMRs that can navigate in complex, indoor environments where global positioning systems (GPS) are not allowed by providing contactless deliveries of food, beverages, and other retail products to travelers at the gate.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project investigates a hybrid collision avoidance approach enabling autonomous mobile robots (AMRs) to operate safely in dense crowds, while being socially-compliant in sparse scenarios. Preliminary research has shown that Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL)-based approaches can compute collision-free robot velocities with inaccurate, uncertain perception data. The proposed DRL-based model will be implemented as an optimized neural network that works on power and cost-efficient embedded processors.  The key technical hurdles in this technology are: the DRL model trained in simulation may not perform well in real-world environments (known as sim-to-real gap), the fully-trained DRL model may have some performance degradation compared to the company’s current DRL models due to the lower number of parameters used to run on embedded processors, and the localization modules could compute erroneous locations when the AMR is navigating through a dense crowd due to occlusions. The key objectives of Phase I are to address these challenges.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
In the realm of robotics, the development of navigation systems that can seamlessly maneuver through various environments, particularly those involving human interaction, is a significant challenge. Our project, conducted under the NSF Phase I project, showcases a novel hybrid navigation stack that effectively addresses these challenges. This hybrid navigation system is primarily composed of two modules: a probabilistic cost module and a socially compliant cost module. 

The probabilistic cost module, integrated with the Dynamic Window Approach (DWA) and Timed Elastic Band (TEB) local planners, is highly effective in densely populated areas. It excels in predicting and avoiding paths that cross with pedestrians, thereby ensuring safety and efficiency in navigating through crowds. The socially compliant module comprises submodules designed for specific scenarios such as detecting and avoiding groups of people, crossing behavior and navigating corridors in appropriate lanes. This hybrid strategy is designed to smoothly transition between these modules, balancing the varying costs and priorities of each situation on the map. While the primary focus is on collision-free and safe navigation, the system also places a considerable emphasis on social compliance, ensuring that the robot's movements are respectful and non-intrusive in social environments.

Through both real-world and simulated testing, we observed notable improvements in the robot's navigation path choices. In crowded scenarios, the integration of the DWA with the probabilistic cost algorithm allowed the robot to navigate safely avoiding collisions in densely crowded environments. In contrast, in less crowded public places, the socially compliant modules ensured the robot's navigation paths were safe and unobtrusive.

In addition to the development of the hybrid navigation stack, our project also involved developing a cloud platform tailored for robotics use cases. This was inspired by insights gained from customer discovery interviews and participation in programs like Beat the Odds Bootcamp and the NSF All SBIR I-Corps. The need for a platform that allows for easy testing and evaluation of different robotics algorithms was evident from the customer discovery interviews. This cloud-based system facilitates and accelerates the robotics development process, enabling quick and efficient comparison of various algorithms, including our hybrid navigation algorithm.

The development of this hybrid navigation system and the cloud robotics platform not only demonstrates significant technological advancements but also highlights our commitment to enhancing the robotics industry's growth. By offering our tools on a cloud platform, we have made significant strides in making advanced robotics technology more accessible and streamlined for the autonomous mobile robotics industry. This approach not only improves efficiency in the development process but also provides advanced algorithms to ensure that the robots of the future are both safe and socially-compliant, an essential aspect of integrating robotics into human-centric public environments.

 


Last Modified: 01/18/2024
Modified by: Utsav V Patel
